edu.iastate.cs228.hw2

Class AbstractSorter

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.iastate.cs228.hw2.AbstractSorter
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    InsertionSorter, MergeSorter, QuickSorter, SelectionSorter

    public abstract class AbstractSorter
extends java.lang.Object
    This abstract class is extended by SelectionSort, InsertionSort, MergeSort, and QuickSort. It stores the input (later the sorted) sequence and records the employed sorting algorithm, the comparison method, and the time spent on sorting.

      protected long sortingTime

      void writePointsToFile()
      This method, called after sorting, writes point data into a file by outputFileName.
      The format of data in the file is the same as printed out from toString().
      The file can help you verify the full correctness of a sorting result and debug the underlying algorithm.

    • Constructor Detail

      • AbstractSorter

        protected AbstractSorter()

      • AbstractSorter

        protected AbstractSorter(Point[] pts)
                  throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        This constructor accepts an array of points as input. Copy the points into the array points[]. Sets the instance variable lowestPoint.
        Parameters:
        pts - input array of points
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if pts == null or pts.length == 0.

      • AbstractSorter

        protected AbstractSorter(java.lang.String inputFileName)
                  throws java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                         java.util.InputMismatchException
        This constructor reads points from a file. Sets the instance variables lowestPoint and outputFileName.
        Parameters:
        inputFileName -
        Throws:
        java.io.FileNotFoundException
        java.util.InputMismatchException - when the input file contains an odd number of integers

    • Method Detail

      • sort

        public abstract void sort(int order)
                   throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Sorts the elements in points[]. a) in the non-decreasing order of x-coordinate if order == 1 b) in the non-decreasing order of polar angle w.r.t. lowestPoint if order == 2 (lowestPoint will be at index 0 after sorting) Sets the instance variable sortByAngle based on the value of order. Calls the method setComparator() to set the variable pointComparator and use it in sorting. Records the sorting time (in nanoseconds) using the System.nanoTime() method. (Assign the time spent to the variable sortingTime.)
        Parameters:
        order - 1 by x-coordinate 2 by polar angle w.r.t lowestPoint
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if order is less than 1 or greater than 2

      • stats

        public java.lang.String stats()
        Outputs performance statistics in the format: For instance, selection sort 1000 9200867 Use the spacing in the sample run in Section 2 of the project description.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Write points[] to a string. When printed, the points will appear in order of increasing index with every point occupying a separate line. The x and y coordinates of the point are displayed on the same line with exactly one blank space in between.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • writePointsToFile

        public void writePointsToFile()
                       throws java.io.FileNotFoundException
        This method, called after sorting, writes point data into a file by outputFileName.
        The format of data in the file is the same as printed out from toString().
        The file can help you verify the full correctness of a sorting result and debug the underlying algorithm.
        Throws:
        java.io.FileNotFoundException

      • draw

        public void draw()
        This method is called after sorting for visually check whether the result is correct. You just need to generate a list of points and a list of segments, depending on the value of sortByAngle, as detailed in Section 4.1. Then create a Plot object to call the method myFrame().

      • setComparator

        protected void setComparator(int order)
        Generates a comparator on the fly that compares by polar angle if sortByAngle == true and by x-coordinate if sortByAngle == false. Set the protected variable pointComparator to it. Need to create an object of the PolarAngleComparator class and call the compareTo() method in the Point class, respectively for the two possible values of sortByAngle.
        Parameters:
        order -

      • swap

        protected void swap(int i,
                    int j)
        Swap the two elements indexed at i and j respectively in the array points[].
        Parameters:
        i -
        j -
